subject: RE: [junit] Testing super-class contracts (test case reuse)
msgSnippet: Here s one way: Create a new test case, and make the class abstract. Declare an InputStream member variable. Create an abstract method with the signature
messageBody:
Here's one way:

Create a new test case, and make the class abstract.
Declare an InputStream member variable.
Create an abstract method with the signature

InputStream makeStream()

Set the earlier member variable to the result of that call in setUp()
Write your test cases to the interface.

When testing one of your custom streams, derive from this
abstract test class, and override the makeStream() method to
return your custom implementation.

Add any other test cases specific to this implementation.

Is that the kind of thing you were thinking of?

> -----Original Message-----
> From: Tharp, Joshua L, SOLGV [mailto:jltharp@...]
> Sent: 19 June 2003 23:10
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: [junit] Testing super-class contracts (test case reuse)
>
>
> I'm new to the list, so I apologize if this topic has been
> hashed over before. I tried searching the archives, but found
> nothing applicable. If this is an old topic, I would
> appreciate a pointer to the thread...
>
>
>
> Background:
>
> I have written several derivatives of java.io.InputStream and
> test cases that go along with them. However, during a recent
> peer review of the code, we discovered an inconsistency
> between the contract of one of the methods in
> java.io.InputStream and my implementation of that same method
> in the specialized subclass.
>
>
>
> Problem:
>
> I would like to have a set of functional tests (black-box
> style) that enforce the behaviors of the super class,
> java.io.InputStream. Then use that same set of tests to
> ensure that the basic contracts for each of the classes I
> write follow that contract (i.e. pass those generic tests).
> Does anyone have a suggestion for doing this? While this
> specific example pertains to java.io.InputStream the same
> scenario may occur with any class hierarchy.
>
>
>
> Environment:
>
> I use Ant to compile and run my tests, so ideally any
> solution will be compatible with the <batchtest> mechanism or
> otherwise allow for the dynamic (read, "automatic") addition
> of new tests.
>
>
>
> Thanks,
>
>
>
> Josh
